bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to W.S. Lemon, January 20, 1938

div1.p: Hench confirms with Lemon his invitation for Kissinger to come to the Mayo Clinic. Lemon's response to Hench is typed on the same page.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to W.S. Lemon, January 20, 1938
div1.p:
I have heard from Mr. Kissinger, the yellow fever man. He will be
in Florida until about the 10th of May, which probably means that he couldn't
speak here until the latter part of May, and this would suit me, because I
will be in Europe, arriving home about the 19th of May, and I should like to
be here when he arrives for various reasons. First, I have invited him to
be a house guest. Second, Harry Harwick permitted me to let both him and his
wife go through the clinic without expense to them if I would supervise their
examinations. Third, and most important, I am going to help Kissinger write
up his story to be published in some medical journal. Ed Allen tells me
that the last week in May is all right as far as he is concerned. Shall I
write him tentatively to that effect?
div1.closer:
P.S. Hench, 1-20-38 Dr. Hench:
I think the last week in May will be all right.
-W. S. Lemon, 1-20-38
